--- title: Lecture 01a -- Welcome subtitle: ENVX2001 Applied Statistical Methods date: last-modified date-format: "MMM YYYY" author: - name: "Januar Harianto" email: "januar.harianto@sydney.edu.au" orcid: "0000-0001-5678-9012" affiliation: Lecturer, SOLES attributes: corresponding: true format: ochre-revealjs: default ochre-typst: fig-format: png --- # About Staff | Structure | Attendance ## Staff ::: {layout-ncol=4 style="text-align:center;"} ![A. Prof Aaron Greenville
Unit Coordinator
Weeks 4-6](images/aaron.tiff){height=300} ![Dr Liana Pozza
Lecturer
Weeks 7-9](images/liana.jpeg){height=300} ![Dr Januar Harianto
Lecturer
Weeks 1-3](images/januar.jpeg){height=300} ![Prof Mathew Crowther
Professor
Weeks 9-11](images/matcrowther.jpeg){height=300} ::: ## Structure ### Scheduled sessions - Lectures run **Wednesdays 10 am–12 pm** in [Chemistry Lecture Theatre 3][clt03]. - Labs are held at the **South Eveleigh Precinct** — Thursdays 9 am–12 pm, Fridays 10 am–1 pm or 2–5 pm. ### Getting help - Post on **Ed** for questions — we usually respond the same day (weekdays). - **Drop-in sessions** (Zoom or in person) are available on request — just send us an email or post on Ed. ## Attendance 1. **Lectures**: Compulsory, but **not** a hurdle. If you choose to watch the recordings, understand that academic decisions (e.g. review of exams) will be made based on your attendance records for lectures and labs. 2. **Labs**: Mandatory, 80% minimum attendance required. Attendance will be taken by QR code. If you miss a lab, you may attend another session that week -- send us an email! 3. **Tutorials**: Self-guided (1 hour), complete before each week's lab. ## Assessments Check [Unit Outline](https://www.sydney.edu.au/units/ENVX2001/2026-S1C-ND-CC) | Week | Assessment | Weight | Type | |------|-------------------------------------------|---------|------------| | 3 | Early Feedback Task | 1% | Individual | | 5 | Project 1: Describing data | 10% | Individual | | 10 | Project 2: Analysing experimental data | 20% | Individual | | 13 | Project 3: Presentation (multivariate) | 20% | Group | | - | Quizzes (weekly, multiple due dates) | 4% | Individual | | - | Exam (2 hours, MCQs + Short Answers) | 45% | Individual | # South Eveleigh Precinct Used to be known as the **Australian Technology Park** (ATP). *Still is, but it used to, too.* ## Biomedical Building ![Credit: Michael Wheatland](images/biomedical.jpg) ## Directions ### Buses [Courtesy buses][buses] are available: - The best option is to take the bus from **Fisher Library** to **Redfern Station**, then walk to the precinct (through the new station platform as “local traffic”). - Alternatively, direct buses are available -- but less frequent. ### Driving Free parking is available around Henderson Road, but it is extremely crowded. We do *not* recommend driving to the precinct. ## Walking Walking to the South Eveleigh Precinct takes about 20 minutes. However, you can save approximately 5 minutes by using Redfern station's community access gates, where you don't need to use an Opal card to get through. [If the map does not load, click here](https://maps.app.goo.gl/vs6aXA6YY4cL98Po7) # Your Statistical journey ## Does migration come at a cost? In a partially migratory elk population in Alberta, Canada, researchers compared calf birth weights between resident and migrant herds. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-revealjs/elk-birthweight-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: *You'll learn to compare groups like this with **t-tests** (Weeks 1--3).* ## Can crop rotation restore soil health? A greenhouse experiment tested how soil conditioned by different crops affects the growth of subsequent plantings. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-revealjs/crop-rotation-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: *You'll learn to compare multiple treatments with **ANOVA** (Weeks 3--6).* ## How are plants adapting to drought? Capeweed populations collected across a natural aridity gradient in southern Australia were grown under controlled conditions to test whether plants from drier areas had evolved drought-resistant traits. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-revealjs/plant-aridity-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: *You'll learn to model relationships like this with **regression** (Weeks 7--9).* ## Darwin's finches: evolution you can measure Peter and Rosemary Grant spent 40 years measuring beak morphology in Galápagos finches, documenting natural selection in real time. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-revealjs/darwin-finches-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: *You'll learn to find patterns in complex datasets with **multivariate methods** (Weeks 10--12).* # Doing well ## Lecture attendance options ### In-person vs. online recordings ::: fragment **In-person benefits:** - Real-time interaction with peers and lecturers - Immediate feedback and clarification of concepts - Active participation in discussions and polls - Building connections with classmates **Online recording benefits:** - Flexibility to manage other commitments - Ability to pause and review complex concepts - Learn at your own pace - Convenient for those with long commutes ::: ## On-campus or online? Choose the option that best suits your learning style and circumstances. **If watching online, try to**: - Stay up to date with recordings to avoid falling behind - Use Ed discussion board actively for questions - **Attend some lectures in person when possible for key topics** There is a strong positive correlation between lecture attendance and final grades -- but it's not the only factor. *It may just be the case that students who attend lectures are more likely to keep up with the course material.* ## Put in the hours - This is a **6 credit point** unit, which means that you are expected to spend **120 -- 150 hours** in total, including exam prep time (~10 h per week)! - **Practice makes perfect**. Tutorials and Labs help you apply the concepts you learn in lectures -- complete all the exercises, and practice with the bonus questions provided. ![](images/adventuretime.gif){fig-align="center" height=350} ## Ask questions - [**Ed**][edsite] is the *best* place to ask questions. We are way more responsive on **Ed** than on email. - We are *open* to the use of AI tools (including LLMs like ChatGPT) to help you answer questions about code... but don't use them to cheat *yourself* out of learning. - We have **drop-in sessions**, where you can jump in and have a chat on Zoom. We will announce the schedule on **Ed**. # Learning outcomes ## By the end of this course, we want you to be able to: - **LO1** demonstrate proficiency in designing sample schemes and analysing data from them **using R**. - **LO2** describe and identify the basic features of an **experimental design**: replicate, treatment structure and blocking structure. - **LO3** demonstrate proficiency in the use or the statistical programming language **R** to apply an ANOVA and fit regression models to experimental data. - **LO4** demonstrate proficiency in the use or the statistical programming language **R** to use multivariate methods to find patterns in data. - **LO5** interpret the output and understand conceptually how its derived of a regression, ANOVA and multivariate analysis that have been calculated by R. - **LO6** write statistical and modelling results as part of a scientific report. - **LO7** appraise the validity of statistical analyses used publications. # Thanks for listening! Questions? This presentation is based on the [SOLES Quarto reveal.js template](https://github.com/usyd-soles-edu/soles-revealjs) and is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License][cc-by] [clt01]: https://venueweb.sydney.edu.au/F11.01.145 [clt03]: https://venueweb.sydney.edu.au/F11.02.238 [cc-by]: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ [buses]: https://www.sydney.edu.au/about-us/campuses/getting-to-campus/campus-bus-timetables.html [edsite]:https://edstem.org/au/dashboard

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
